fields.body:
A trifle late. Here are the transcribed notes to his collected stories in The Jack Vance Treasury. Even without the frame of the book, I hoped you could still find these edifying. 

"Liane the Wayfarer"
I am aware of using no inflexible or predetermined style. Each story generates its own style, so to speak. In theory, I feel that the only good style is the style which no one notices, but I suppose that in practice this may not be altogether or at all times possible. In actuality the subject of style is much too large to be covered in a sentence or two and no doubt any writer has his own ideas on the subject. -1976

"Sail 25"
Several years ago, Cele Goldsmith edited Amazing Stories. One evening at the home of Poul Anderson she produced a set of cover illustrations which she had bought by the dozen for reasons of economy, and asked those present to formulate stories based upon them. Poul rather gingerly accepted a cover whose subject I forget. Frank Herbert was assigned the representation of a human head, with a cutaway revealing an inferno of hellfire, scurrying half-human creatures, and the paraphernalia of a nuclear power plant. I was rather more fortunate and received a picture purporting to display a fleet of spaceships driven by sun-sails. 
Theoretically the idea is sound, and space scientists have long included this concept among their speculations for future planetary voyages. Astrogation, of course, becomes immensely complex, but by carefully canting the sail and using planetary and/or solar gravities, any region of the solar system may be visited -- not always by the most direct route, but neither did the clipper ships sail great-circle routes. The disadvantages are the complication of the gear and the tremendous expanse of sail -- to be measured in square miles -- necessary to accelerate any mass of ship to any appreciable velocity within a reasonable time-span.

Which brings me back to my cover picture. The artist, no doubt for purposes of artistry, had depicted the ships with sails about the size of spinnakers for a twelve-meter, which at Earth radius from the sun would possibly produce as much as one fly-power of thrust. Additionally the sails were painted in gaudy colors, in defiance of the conventional wisdom which specifies that sun-sails shall be flimsy membranes of plastic, coated with a film of reflective metal a few molecules thick. Still, no matter how illogical the illustration, I felt that I must justify each detail by one means or another. After considerable toil I succeeded, with enormous gratitude that I had not been selected to write about the cutaway head which had been the lot of Frank Herbert. -1976

"The Miracle Workers"
Strange things happen. Almost everyone has had some sort of brush with the paranormal, even the most resistant and skeptical of persons.The range of events is wide and only roughly amenable to classification. In olden times angels and demons were held responsible; to date no one has produced a more reasonable explanation. Phenomena such as telepathy and poltergeists may well be manifestations of different and distinct principles; there may be two, three, four, or more such realms of knowledge, each at least as rich and intricate as physics or astronomy. There is little systematic study. Conventional scientists shy away from the field because they are, in fact, conventional; because they fear to compromise their careers; because the subject is difficult to get a grip on; because scientists are as susceptable to awe and eeriness as anyone else. So the mysteries persist; the lore accumulates, and we know for sure no more than our remote ancestors, if as much... "The Miracle Workers [has a] definite psionic orientation, and [makes] at least a superficial inquiry into certain aspects and implications of telekinesis and demon-possession. I can't pretend to offer enlightenment; there isn't any to be had. The [story], in any event, [was] not conceived as [an] argumentative [vehicle], but simply [reflects] my own fascination with the vast and wonderful reaches of the unknown. -1970

"Guyal of Sfere"
I wrote while I was at sea. I did this Dying Earth thing... I wrote that, sitting looking at the water, and then I got tired of that particular life for various reasons. -1983

"Noise"
Today is a wonderful time to be alive -- the most exciting and colorful age in the whole tremendous history of man. We are in a period of change-over, from a civilization based of European ideas that has lost its momentum and grown tired, to a new civilization on whose basic patterns we are still working. No one could call this an era of calm; quite the reverse. Events come at us with a rapidity that bewilders most people and alarms not a few. Science fiction provides a primary education for this new age exactly as history and geography books have educated us for the present. Science fiction gives us a head start at fitting ourselves to the new conditions, and we have an enormous advantage over people who ignore the future. -1953

"The Overworld"
I was one of those precocious, highly intelligent kids, old beyond my years. I had lots of brothers and sisters, but I was isolated from them in a certain kind of way. I just read and read and read. One of the things I read was the old Weird Tales magazine, which published Clark Ashton Smith. He was one of the generative geniuses of fantasy... Smith is a little clumsy at times, but at least his prose is always readable.

When I wrote my first fantasies, I was no longer aware of Smith -- it had sunk so far into my subconscious. But when it was pointed out to me, I could very readily see the influence. - 1983

"The Sorceror Pharesm"
Motivations are naturally the important components of any story -- the dynamic essence, so to speak. Lacking motivations -- obsessions, lust, greed, fear, revenge -- the story becomes a pastoral idyll, an impressionistic sketch. It should be noted that no one seems interested in reading about virtue.

Frank Herbert had a... formula. He wrote it out, P-R-E-S-S-U-R-E. Coincedentally, at the time he mentioned this to me, he had just published a story called Under Pressure. He felt then that at all times your characters have to be under pressure to move, to be forced to move one way or the other. Well, this is no doubt true. As for myself, I don't adhere to formulas of any sort. I don't trust them. I don't think you can write on the basis of rules. If you keep some slogan in front of your mind while you're writing, you'll be limiting yourself. - 1977

"The Moon Moth"
The symbolic adjuncts used to enlarge the human personality are of course numerous. Clothes comprise a most important category of these symbols and sometimes when people are gathered together it is amusing to examine garments, unobtrusively of course, and to reflect that each article has been selected with solicitous care with the intention of creating some particular effect.

Despite the symbolic power of clothes, men ane women are judged, by and large, by circumstances more difficult to control: posture, accent, voice timbre, the shape and color of their bodies, and most significant of all, their faces. Voices can be modulated, diets and exercise, theoretically at least, force the body into socially acceptable contours. What can be done to the face? Enormous effort has been expended in this direction. Jowls are hoisted, eyebrows attached or eliminated, noses cropped, de-hooked, de-humped. The hair is tormented into a thousand styles: puffed, teased, wet, dried, hung this way or that: all to formulate a fashionable image. Nonetheless, all pretenses are transparent: nature-fakery yields to the critical eye. No matter what our inclinations, whether or not we like our faces, we are forced to live with them, and to accept whatever favor, censure or derision we willy-nilly incur. 

Except those intricate and intelligent folk of the world Sirene, whose unorthodox social habits are considered in the [preceding] pages. -1976

"The Bagful of Dreams"
The less a writer discusses his work -- and himself -- the better. The master chef slaughters no chickens in the dining room; the doctor writes prescriptions in Latin; the magician hides his hinges, mirrors, and trapdoors with the utmost care.

Recently I read of a surgeon who, after performing a complicated abortion, displayed to the ex-mother the fetus in a jar of formaldehyde. The woman went into hysterics and sued him, and I believe collected. No writer has yet been hauled into court on similar grounds, but the day may arrive. -1975

"Morreion"
I feel rather like a stage magician with a repertory of tricks; we both create illusions. Does he go to great effort to explain his techniques? -1977

"The Last Castle"
Sometimes the source of a story is a mystery even to the writer himself: a seepage from his subconscious. Other times the derivation is clear and direct. In the case of "The Last Castle," both situations are equally true.

The germ of the story was contained in an article dealing with Japanese social interactions. As is well knwon, Japanese society is highly formalized -- much more thoroughly so in the past than during the relatively egalitarian times since the last war.

During the nineteenth century, when a samurai deigned to converse with a person of lower rank, each used markedly different vocabularies, with honorifics precisely calculated to the difference in status. When the person of lower degree discussed the samurai's activities or intentions, he used a special convention. Never would he pose a simple question such as: "Will your lordship go boar-hunting tomorrow?" This would impute to his lordship a coarse and undignified fervor, a sweating, earnest, lip-licking zeal, which his lordship would have found offensively below his dignity. Instead the underling might ask: "Will your lordship tomorrow amuse himself by trifling at the hunting of a boar?"

In short, the aristocrat was conceded sensibilities of such exquisite nicety, competences of such awful grandeur, that he need only toy with all ordinary activities, in a mood of whimsy or caprice, in order to achieve dazzling successes.

So, "The Last Castle" concerns a society of somewhat similar folk, and examines their behavior when the society is subjected to great stress. -1976
fields.title: Vance Week addendum - V08

fields.body:
Professors Roberto Mangabeira Unger and Michael Puett (Faculty of Arts and
Sciences)
2 classroom credits LAW-46261A

This course is a comparative inquiry into certain forms of moral consciousness and their metaphysical assumptions in the high cultures of
Eurasia. We organize discussion around a broad background concern as well as a focused foreground theme.

The background concern is the meaning or meaninglessness of human life: comparison of some of the ways in which philosophy, religion, and art in the East and the West have dealt with the fear that our lives and the world itself may be meaningless.

The foreground theme is the contrast between two answers to the question --how should I live my life?  One answer, valuing serenity achieved through
disengagement from illusion and vain striving, is: stay out of trouble.  Another answer, prizing the acceptance of vulnerability for the sake of
self-construction and self-transformation is: look for trouble.

The second answer has come to play a major part in the moral and political projects that command attention throughout the world today. We seek to
understand this second answer and to assess it in the light of speculative ideas that have been prominent in Eastern and Western thought. Conversely, we use our chosen theme to explore how Eastern and Western speculation have dealt with the limits of insight into what matters most. To these ends, we consider exemplary writings from several traditions: Chinese, South Asian, ancient Greek, and modern European.
fields.title: Self, Serenity, and Vulnerability (law school course)

America's primary race problem today is our new "sophistication" around racial matters. Political correctness is a compendium of sophistications in which we join ourselves to obvious falsehoods ("diversity") and refuse to see obvious realities (the irrelevance of diversity to minority development). I would argue further that Barack Obama's election to the presidency of the United States was essentially an American sophistication, a national exercise in seeing what was not there and a refusal to see what was there—all to escape the stigma not of stupidity but of racism.

http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704254604574614540488450188.html?mod=rss_Today's_Most_Popular

fields.body:
Preamble: I am white.

Exhibits:

(A) One time, as a college freshman, a white friend introduced me to her black roommate. I don't remember the entire scene clearly, but I recall Roommate showing us her teddy bears. I want to think that the white one's name was something like Whitey, but Roommate's horrified response--the part I do remember clearly--when I suggested with gusto that the other one was called Blackie, indicates to me that perhaps I had named the first as well.

(B) A few years ago, I picked up a black guy in a suit walking on Duss Ave. (This is well after I picked up the other black guy in a suit who called himself St. John and turned out to be a con artist. IIRC, reo sponsored a trip to gov't housing in Aliquippa as part of that episode ['tempo' means time!?], which I believe also featured rtelep sagely observing, "What's the worst thing that can happen, he takes lots of your money? That's not so bad."). The guy was walking to work, as it turns out, at the Chevy dealership a block from my house. I suggested forcefully--despite the suit--that he was a mechanic at said dealership. Of course, he was a salesman. (Haven't seen him since, btw.)

(C) Another time I tried to offer a ride to a black guy. He didn't want a ride. It was starting to storm, and I insisted in a presumptuous sort of way, after waiting in a presumptuous sort of way for him to walk the 40 yards or so to where I had pulled off, that he should get in the car. He refused, bristling.

(D) Back to college: I ended up in a meeting of a "Diversity Initiative" discussion group. A black student asked me pointedly why I was uncomfortable talking about diversity issues. I was very uncomfortable.

Those are the incidents about which I feel most ashamed of myself racism-wise.

I had a conversion experience a little over a year ago, coincident with a flurry of XMin activity, in which I decided that I was willing to be identified with all people ("humans"). That is, I desire to not be ashamed to appear to be identified with any given human or group of humans.

I have actually been surprised to discover that personal racial equilibrium (if you will) has been a side-effect of this absolute identificationary willingness (AIW?). A former sense of dread at "saying the wrong thing" in potentially-racially-charged situations is diffused, in my experience, when I proactively engage with people--"humans", "the Other"--on an interpersonal level, "as humans."

Of course, on the other hand, I am also required by AIW to be willing to be identified with Glenn, Sean, Rush, Pat, and the tradition of White Supremacy.

I am finding Black Studies to be increasingly interesting. I recognize and admit that it is a huge part of the meaning of America, as well as being interesting because of the centrality of the interplay between group and individual.

At this point I find myself liking Steele, and then Gates. Smiley and West strike me as activists, which is to say, oversimplifiers. But there's a place for that, I suppose.

I don't think Glenn Beck is as bad as I think Rick thinks he is. I think he is probably essentially Steele-like in his thinking, but like Smiley/West he is an activist, which is to say, an oversimplifier--though more brazen, certainly.

The most confusing part about the whole thing, IMO, on both sides (supremacy, blackness), is the relationship of group and individual.

fields.body:
Just wanted to chime in to say I'm reading all this stuff.  I'm working a lot now and it's draining a lot of my energy, so when I'm home I decompress and socialize and read and sleep.  But the thoughts and dialogues and subjects have been very engaging for me.  There are so many, and yet it's happening too fast for my schedule!   

Whit, I like Black Studies, too.  I'm glad you're diggin the ABCL book.  I'm in the middle of it now.  I really like it, too.  Yesterday morning I read Lenora Fulani's essay.  Never knew about her.  I liked it.  
She started cool educational programs and has this kinda unique spin on the matter.  She's interested in pushing people beyond their comfort zones, so she asks brown-skinned, economically deprived kids if they wanna start acting in plays.  She believes that the hip hop identity is a performance, and they can learn other performances (like cultural scripts in office settings, or what it's like to wear suits), by performing in plays.  Then she gives them internships on Wall Street.  Then they learn that they can have other identities, too, and make some money, and they get more sophisticated in terms of learning to shift their behavior according to whatever setting their in.  She says bluntly, "We teach them to be white."  

I have to go now and bring a 300 pound guy to the clinic for a colonoscopy.  

Yesterday I had to go to the doctor, due to intense pain in my pelvis for approx. two weeks.  I thought it was a hernia, and I thought I needed surgery.  Turns out I just have tendonitis.  PHEW.  I had to pay outta pocket, and that sucked.  But then they gave me a discount, so that was great.  Only 35 bucks!  Awesome.    

I will comment more at the next available juncture in which I can give FMR my full attention.  I will comment on specific topics.  I just got another collection of essays for Christmas called "When Law Fails," which is a collection of a lot of essays by lawyers and profs trying to make sense of criminal justice problems.  I learned about it through this link:  

http://www.charleshamiltonhouston.org/Home.aspx

I will bring what I have and what I am to the table on race matters.  I am not a "saint."  Cornel West is not a "saint."  Shelby Steele is not a "demon."  Henry Louis Gates is not an "angel."  I am not "moralizing" or "crusading."  I am interested in thinking about race matters, and doing shit about it.  The book, the Covenant, is instructive for telling us what we can do.  I think we're doing a lot right now, just by talking about it.  I think we can do more. I think that book helps us see that we can be involved in groups or issues that touch the problem, and then we can be a voice or a resource of some kind for those issues.  And I agree, there is a lot to be done on the personal level.  That will help a lot.  

okay.  now i really gotta go.

"Milwaukee remains more segregated than any other metro area. Nationwide, U.S. suburbs are 39% black. Milwaukee's suburbs are only 5% black. In 2000, 69% of Milwaukee's whites lived in suburbs, while 95% of blacks lived in the city of Milwaukee.

Wisconsin has the highest black unemployment rate in the Midwest. In 2002, 52% of Milwaukee's working-age blacks were unemployed, up from 38.4% in 2000.

In a 2001 study, pairs of black and white college students, using similar resumes, applied for 350 low-skill jobs advertised in the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. Some of these testers were assigned fake prison records.

Employers called back 34% of the whites without records and 17% of whites with records, but only 14% of blacks without records. Thus, employers preferred white criminals over law-abiding blacks. Overall, they were three times more likely to hire whites."

there is a lot of research like this out there.  i think it's instructive.

fields.body:
Five primary indicators of quality of life are used: (1) the level of civil order; (2) municipal services; (3) the physical environment; (4) functional adequacy; and (5) leisure activities within cities. Census data and FBI crime report data were relied upon, as well as interviews.

Each of the study cities experienced improvement in some of these five broad quality of life indicators in the 1990s; generally, the cities fit within a continuum. At one extreme, Pittsburgh experienced consistently low crime rates, ranked high in school resources and test scores, showed substantial increases in median house value and decreases in infant mortality rates, and it was the only city to improve in air quality. In the middle of the continuum, Cleveland, Milwaukee, and St. Louis each showed more modest improvements in several indicators and all experienced significant improvement in median value of housing units and infant mortality rates. At the other extreme, Baltimore ranks lowest overall. Despite improvements in both property and violent crimes, Baltimore still consistently ranks among the worst in crime rates. Although Baltimore has the highest median value of owner occupied housing, it ranks worst in other housing measures and ranks only average in terms of municipal services, physical environment, functional adequacy, and leisure.



Excerpted from:
http://ips.jhu.edu/pub/Is-There-An-Urban-Revival-and-What-Does-It-Mean-for-Baltimore
fields.title: Is There An 'Urban Revival' and What Does It Mean for Baltimore?

""How now brown cow" is a phrase used in elocution teaching to demonstrate rounded vowel sounds. Each "ow" sound in the phrase represents an individual diphthong. The phrase does not have an explicit meaning per se but can be used as a light-hearted greeting.[1] Although the exact origins of the phrase are unclear, it can be dated to at least 1942 in the United States.[1] In February of that year the Maryland newspaper The Capital mentioned the phrase when discussing a famous thespian's voice:
Laird Cregar, now contributing his booming voice to 'Ten Gentlemen from West Point': explains how he got it. When he first tried out for the Pasadena Community Playhouse his voice wouldn't carry past the front rows. Coach Belle Kennedy had him declaim 'How, Now, Brown Cow? and The Rain in Spain Still Stains' - over and over.[1]"

Excerpted from:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_now_brown_cow
fields.title: How now brown cow

fields.body:
The relationship between Barack Obama and Joe Biden grew so strained during the 2008 campaign, according to a new book, that the two rarely spoke and aides not only kept Biden off internal conference calls but refused to even tell him they existed.

Instead, a separate campaign call was regularly scheduled between the then-Delaware senator and two of Obama’s top campaign aides – “so that they could keep a tight rein on him,” write journalists Mark Halperin and John Heilemann in “Game Change,” a long-awaited account of the 2008 campaign.

The book, based on over 300 interviews, reveals a series of previously undisclosed stories about the epic race. POLITICO obtained it Saturday at a Washington bookstore.

In addition to the discord between the president and vice-president, the authors write:

–Before the 2004 Democratic presidential primary, party strategists Mark Penn and Mandy Grunwald, both then working for Sen. Joe Lieberman’s presidential candidacy, met secretly with then-Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton and a group of her closest confidantes to consider a last-minute entry into the race – and even polled New Hampshire voters about the idea. Ultimately, though, Chelsea Clinton persuaded her mother to opt out of a run, arguing that voters wouldn’t forgive her for breaking a pledge to serve a full Senate term.

–Sen. Majority Leader Harry Reid, Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-NY), and a group of other senators who would back Hillary Clinton’s candidacy encouraged Obama to run for the White House as early as 2006. The concern over Clinton was that she would be a weak Democratic standard-bearer while Obama could energize the party. In late summer 2007, Schumer – using an Obama ally, Sen. Claire McCaskill (D-MO), as a back channel – pushed the candidate to “take a two-by-four to Hillary,” as the authors put it.

–In lobbying the late Sen. Edward Kennedy to endorse his wife, former President Clinton angered the liberal icon by belittling Obama. Telling a friend about the conversation, Kennedy recalled Clinton had said “a few years ago, this guy would have been getting us coffee,” the authors paraphrase. A spokesman for the former president declined to comment on the claim.

–Frustrated over the campaign following her disastrous interview with Katie Couric, Sarah Palin said she regretted accepting the Republican vice presidential nomination. “If I’d known everything I know now, I would not have done this,” she said. McCain’s high command, already worried about her lack of eating and drinking and fearing that she was suffering from post-partum depression, convened a conference call and discussed whether she was mentally unstable.

Palin spokeswoman Meg Stapleton issued a statement in response to "Game Change" touting the former governor's own insider account.

"The Governor's descriptions of these events are found in her book, 'Going Rogue,'” said Stapleton. “Her descriptions are accurate. She was there. These reporters were not.”

–There were apparently "two Americas" within the marriage between John and Elizabeth Edwards. The former North Carolina senator's wife viewed herself as a worldly intellectual and publicly called her husband "a hick" and his parents "rednecks," according to the authors.

"She was forever letting John know she regarded him as her intellectual inferior," they write, mocking her husband, the presidential hopeful, as somebody who "doesn't read books." 

Excerpted from:
http://dyn.politico.com/printstory.cfm?uuid=148616C2-18FE-70B2-A81EB00856517005
fields.title: Book: Obama, Biden clashed in '08 - POLITICO.com Print View

fields.body:
Just when the 2008 campaign seemed slipping below the horizon, Mark Halperin and John Heilemann’s “Game Change” blew across the political landscape this weekend in an explosion of Twitter, blog, cable and MSM coverage.

The book’s successful launch was no surprise to Howard Fineman, Newsweek’s chief political writer, given that Halperin, in his opinion, “more or less created the world that we now live in: the 24-7, always-on, hyperlinked, Web-based, D.C. political media world we live in now with ‘The Note.’”

As founder and editor of ABC’s “The Note,” which began targeting the influential Gang of 500 in 2002, Halperin pioneered the transmission of real-time political news, earning a New Yorker profile in 2004, and later distilling what he know about the viral nature of political news in “The Way to Win,” a book he co-wrote in 2006 with POLITICO Editor-in-Chief John Harris.

Given the reams of real-time coverage of the 2008 race, followed by Newsweek’s lengthy post-election tick-tock and “The Battle for America,” a Dan Balz-Haynes Johnson book on the election that came out last fall, it might be expected that the political press corps had picked the campaign carcass clean long ago.

But Fineman said Halperin and Heilemann “very smartly went after stuff that was undercovered,” such as John and Elizabeth Edwards. And once having such juicy, insider material, Fineman noted that the authors — both residing in New York, the television and publishing capital — are savvy enough to effectively market the material.

In today’s media world, Fineman added, the “tweetable nugget” is the type of thing that quick gets the attention of reporters, and subsequently, readers.

“A long analysis of the demographics of the electorate is not going to get you an HBO movie,” Fineman said. “But the tawdry psycho-drama of the Edwards’s and a racist crack by Harry Reid will.”

Heilemann, a staff writer for New York magazine, and Halperin, formerly at ABC and now at Time, are consummate insiders, and the roll-out of the book reflects that — a veritable drumbeat of blog items and newspaper stories that culminated Sunday night with a segment on “60 Minutes” in which Anderson Cooper interviewed not only them but also Steve Schmidt, the former McCain campaign strategist and an obvious source, who described many of the incidents recounted in the books.


Excerpted from:
http://dyn.politico.com/printstory.cfm?uuid=1AECC264-18FE-70B2-A88C3D2347C82C8B
fields.title: 'Game Change': The freak show - POLITICO.com Print View

fields.body:
"Like many other well-known organizations, we face cyber attacks of varying degrees on a regular basis. In mid-December, we detected a highly sophisticated and targeted attack on our corporate infrastructure originating from China that resulted in the theft of intellectual property from Google. However, it soon became clear that what at first appeared to be solely a security incident--albeit a significant one--was something quite different.

"First, this attack was not just on Google. As part of our investigation we have discovered that at least twenty other large companies from a wide range of businesses--including the Internet, finance, technology, media and chemical sectors--have been similarly targeted. We are currently in the process of notifying those companies, and we are also working with the relevant U.S. authorities."

"Second, we have evidence to suggest that a primary goal of the attackers was accessing the Gmail accounts of Chinese human rights activists."
fields.title: Google vs. China

fields.body:
In December of 1944, whilst behind enemy lines during the Rhineland Campaign, Private Kurt Vonnegut was captured by Wehrmacht troops and subsequently became a prisoner of war. A month later, Vonnegut and his fellow POWs reached a Dresden work camp where they were imprisoned in an underground slaughterhouse known by German soldiers as Schlachthof Fünf (Slaughterhouse Five). The next month - February - the subterranean nature of the prison saved their lives during the highly controversial and devastating bombing of Dresden, the aftermath of which Vonnegut and the remaining survivors helped to clear up.

Vonnegut released the book Slaughterhouse-Five in 1969. 

Below is a letter he wrote to his family that May from a repatriation camp, in which he informs them of his capture and survival. Transcript follows.


Excerpted from:
http://www.lettersofnote.com/2009/11/slaughterhouse-five.html
fields.title: Letters of Note: Slaughterhouse Five

fields.body:
F.

~

Among the horrible images and news, that, to be honest I cannot even look at, I noticed Pat Robertson weighing in on the tragedy.

His take is that Haiti is being fucked by God because they made a deal with the devil to get the French out.

Fuck Pat Robertson, that's what I say.

On one hand you have the American Revolution and all types of Heroic White Beauties; on the other hand, you have the Haitian Revolution, and, well...

N*** getting out of line.  That's what that is.  

Here is another view of the Haitian revolution from wikipedia:

The Haitian Revolution (1791–1804) is the period of violent conflict in the French colony of Saint-Domingue, leading to the elimination of slavery and the establishment of Haiti as the first republic ruled by people of African ancestry. Although hundreds of rebellions occurred in the New World during the centuries of slavery, only the revolt on Saint-Domingue, which began in 1791, was successful in achieving permanent freedom. The Haitian Revolution is regarded as a defining moment in the history of Africans in the new world.

It is no wonder that Sean, Glenn, and Bill seem to be ignoring what's going on down there.  It's just a bunch of ... who got uppity.  "What? We gave adequate coverage. (wink wink.)"

And Rush wants us all to remember that it's just black people down there too. (wink wink.)

(This post is a quick paraphrase of http://mediamatters.org/columns/201001140050)

fields.body:
from an article by naomi klein: 

"Except relief and reconstruction never seem to work like that. When I was in Sri Lanka six months after the tsunami, many survivors told me that the reconstruction was victimizing them all over again. A council of the country's most prominent businesspeople had been put in charge of the process, and they were handing the coast over to tourist developers at a frantic pace. Meanwhile, hundreds of thousands of poor fishing people were still stuck in sweltering inland camps, patrolled by soldiers with machine guns and entirely dependent on relief agencies for food and water. They called reconstruction "the second tsunami."
There are already signs that New Orleans evacuees could face a similarly brutal second storm. Jimmy Reiss, chairman of the New Orleans Business Council, told Newsweek that he has been brainstorming about how "to use this catastrophe as a once-in-an-eon opportunity to change the dynamic." The Business Council's wish list is well-known: low wages, low taxes, more luxury condos and hotels. Before the flood, this highly profitable vision was already displacing thousands of poor African-Americans: While their music and culture was for sale in an increasingly corporatized French Quarter (where only 4.3 percent of residents are black), their housing developments were being torn down. "For white tourists and businesspeople, New Orleans' reputation is 'a great place to have a vacation but don't leave the French Quarter or you'll get shot,'" Jordan Flaherty, a New Orleans-based labor organizer told me the day after he left the city by boat. "Now the developers have their big chance to disperse the obstacle to gentrification--poor people." "  

taken from this article: 

http://www.thenation.com/doc/20050926/klein

There is one interesting idea that I came across over Christmas that I haven't brought up anywhere yet. A Chinese American, in Terkel's book Race, said that Monotheism is a perfect ground for Racism.

It certainly seems to me like the ultimate In/Out dynamic is the salvation and eternal damnation of, say, Christianity.  Not only are *Other* understandings of reality wrong, and allegiances misguided, they actually lead to some sort of horrible eternal torture, perpetual incineration e.g.  This is how we come to "kill the Indian, save the man," and its other form "kill the Indian."

So that, if what you aim to do is to wipe out a people group, steal their stuff, enslave them, demonize them, keep them in ghettos, or begrudge international aid, etc., it is sure handy for them to be in some form of the eternal, ultimate *other*.

The third characteristic of the lion is that when a lioness gives birth to her cubs, she produces them dead and watches over them for three days, until their father comes on the third day and breathes into their faces and restores them to life. Thus the Almighty Father awakened our Lord Jesus Christ from the dead on the third day; as Jacob says: 'He will fall asleep as a lion, and as a lion's whelp he will be revived' (see Genesis, 49:9).

http://www.abdn.ac.uk/bestiary/translat/7v.hti

fields.body:
A Study Of Reading Habits
Philip Larkin


When getting my nose in a book
Cured most things short of school,
It was worth ruining my eyes
To know I could still keep cool,
And deal out the old right hook
To dirty dogs twice my size.

Later, with inch-thick specs,
Evil was just my lark:
Me and my coat and fangs
Had ripping times in the dark.
The women I clubbed with sex!
I broke them up like meringues.

Don't read much now: the dude
Who lets the girl down before
The hero arrives, the chap
Who's yellow and keeps the store
Seem far too familiar. Get stewed:
Books are a load of crap.

Excerpted from:
http://plagiarist.com/poetry/4825/
fields.title: Philip Larkin | "A Study Of Reading Habits" | poetry archive | plagiarist.com

fields.body:
NEW YORK -- J.D. Salinger, the legendary author, youth hero and fugitive from fame whose "The Catcher in the Rye" shocked and inspired a world he increasingly shunned, has died. He was 91.

Salinger died of natural causes at his home on Wednesday, the author's son said in a statement from Salinger's literary representative. He had lived for decades in self-imposed isolation in the small, remote house in Cornish, N.H. 

Excerpted from:
http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/28/AR2010012803177.html
fields.title: 'Catcher in the Rye' author J.D. Salinger dies - washingtonpost.com

fields.body:
J. D. Salinger has died. From 1946 to 1965, Salinger published thirteen stories in The New Yorker, including such classics as “A Perfect Day for Bananafish” and “Raise High the Roof Beam, Carpenters.” There will be much more to come online and in next week’s magazine, but for now, read Salinger’s stories, available to subscribers through our digital edition:

“Slight Rebellion Off Madison” (December 21, 1946)

“A Perfect Day for Bananafish” (January 31, 1948)

“Uncle Wiggly in Connecticut” (March 20, 1948)

“Just Before the War with the Eskimos” (June 5, 1948)

“The Laughing Man” (March 19, 1949)

“For Esmé—With Love and Squalor” (April 8, 1950)

“Pretty Mouth and Green My Eyes” (July 14, 1951)

“Teddy” (January 31, 1953)

“Franny” (January 29, 1955)

“Raise High the Roof Beam, Carpenters” (November 19, 1955)

“Zooey” (May 4, 1957)

“Seymour: An Introduction” (June 6, 1959)

“Hapworth 16, 1924” (June 19, 1965)

Excerpted from:
http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/backissues/2010/01/postscript-j-d-salinger.html
fields.title: Postscript: J. D. Salinger: Back Issues : The New Yorker

fields.body:
Reo and 12 CUT are in a play called "SEX a.k.a. Wieners and Boobs." It is, according to John Staton of the Wilmington Star-News, "utterly ridiculous, completely stupid and thoroughly absurd."

I wanted to go, in the same way that I expect Reo might have come to church with me if I had actually invited him for Christmas. Jess asked me not to attend, because (a) it seemed to her to be morally offensive, and (b) Leah started reading over her shoulder right as she opened the SEX invite in her email, which was upsetting to Jess because it seemed to her to be morally offensive.

Regarding (a) ... SEX is interesting to the people it's interesting to, at least in part, because it's offensive to the people it's offensive to. Raunch, like the bow tie, is a cultural boundary marker.

Regarding (b) ... As my children age, my wife and I find ourselves increasingly in the same uncomfortable position as the governors of China. When Leah has a question ("Is Miley Cyrus a Christian?"), she researches the answer on the Internet. It takes 30 seconds. She's probably doing it right now. My eight-year-old is being democratized, and my authority is threatened. So on the spectrum from Join-the-Amish to Buy-Her-an-iPad, what the wiener am I supposed to do?
fields.title: CHINA a.k.a. Wieners and Boobs

My habit as of last night is to do everything while listening to a Jason Derülo mix on my iPhone via Pandora. Several points:

a) I understand Auto-Tune the News better now.

b) I am engaging popular culture, I think, in a new way.

c) Our discussions of race are in the background here.

d) This turns out to be something that I should do for the sake of my daughters.

e) Jason Derülo, it appears, is Haitian American.


I have stumbled into a cavern.

fields.body:
Obama is notable for inspiring hopeful cultural engagement in American youth, etc. But other aspects of the role countervail: a President must spend 54% of a $2.6T budget on war, for example.

What if Obama were an entertainer instead of a politician? A celebrity like Bono can inspire people towards X. A celebrity must still jet-set, however, and probably ultimately struggles to be taken seriously.

What if Obama were a pastor instead of a politician? A pastor like Rick Warren can inspire people towards X. But a pastor can also give away 90% of his income and live in the same house as when he first got married.

What limits does a pastor have on their inspirational effectiveness?

Which role maximizes charisma's effectiveness in inspiring constructive cultural engagement?

What would happen to celebrity and politics if more inspirational people went for religion?
fields.title: What if Obama were a pastor?

Non eram nescius, Brute, cum, quae summis ingeniis exquisitaque doctrina philosophi Graeco sermone tractavissent, ea Latinis litteris mandaremus, fore ut hic noster labor in varias reprehensiones incurreret. nam quibusdam, et iis quidem non admodum indoctis, totum hoc displicet philosophari. quidam autem non tam id reprehendunt, si remissius agatur, sed tantum studium tamque multam operam ponendam in eo non arbitrantur. erunt etiam, et ii quidem eruditi Graecis litteris, contemnentes Latinas, qui se dicant in Graecis legendis operam malle consumere. postremo aliquos futuros suspicor, qui me ad alias litteras vocent, genus hoc scribendi, etsi sit elegans, personae tamen et dignitatis esse negent. [2] Contra quos omnis dicendum breviter existimo. Quamquam philosophiae quidem vituperatoribus satis responsum est eo libro, quo a nobis philosophia defensa et collaudata est, cum esset accusata et vituperata ab Hortensio. qui liber cum et tibi probatus videretur et iis, quos ego posse iudicare arbitrarer, plura suscepi veritus ne movere hominum studia viderer, retinere non posse. Qui autem, si maxime hoc placeat, moderatius tamen id volunt fieri, difficilem quandam temperantiam postulant in eo, quod semel admissum coerceri reprimique non potest, ut propemodum iustioribus utamur illis, qui omnino avocent a philosophia, quam his, qui rebus infinitis modum constituant in reque eo meliore, quo maior sit, mediocritatem desiderent. [3] Sive enim ad sapientiam perveniri potest, non paranda nobis solum ea, sed fruenda etiam [sapientia] est; sive hoc difficile est, tamen nec modus est ullus investigandi veri, nisi inveneris, et quaerendi defatigatio turpis est, cum id, quod quaeritur, sit pulcherrimum. etenim si delectamur, cum scribimus, quis est tam invidus, qui ab eo nos abducat? sin laboramus, quis est, qui alienae modum statuat industriae? nam ut Terentianus Chremes non inhumanus, qui novum vicinum non vult 'fodere aut arare aut aliquid ferre denique' -- non enim illum ab industria, sed ab inliberali labore deterret --, sic isti curiosi, quos offendit noster minime nobis iniucundus labor.

"Sport, too, is supposed to be just such a pure meritocracy. But is it? Take ice hockey in Canada: look at any team and you will find that a disproportionate number of players will have been born in the first three months of the year. This, it turns out, is because the cut-off date for children eligible for the nine-year-old, 10-year-old, 11-year-old league and so on is January 1. Boys who are oldest and biggest at the beginning of the hockey season are inevitably the best. And so they get the most coaching and practice, and they get chosen for the all-star team, and so their advantage increases - on into the professional game. A similar pattern applies to other sports. What we think of as talent is actually a complicated combination of ability, opportunity and utterly arbitrary advantage."

Sorry, that was cryptic. A few further thoughts.

First, schism is only meaningful if you decide to care about it. Starting from the base level of human consciousness, you have to add something--quite a bit--to get to a point where "schism" means something.

Second, I'm not fully sympathetic to the fine-tuning argument in either form, breeding or purity. Regarding the former, specialization might happen, but I'm not motivated by that. As for returning to an original purity, that isn't really possible, and it's also  antagonistic to what currently exists. I wouldn't claim for XMin that it's purer than Catholicism. Smaller, maybe. ;^)

Schism is just trying something you want to try and seeing if it works. By now there is enough variety in human culture that a little more shouldn't be a big deal. Why should it?

I have lots of thoughts to add to this discussion but it's late and I have to work tomorrow and my wife wants me to get off the computer. :^| But… There are, as I incompletely see it, two reasons to be against schism within the Christian church. The first, which I think Chad is accusing me of, is sentimentality. I have some of that, no doubt. It is the rare and cold human who doesn't. It is at least a social taboo to say that we don't want all of humankind to be a big, happy family. But, it is also not considered a good bedrock on which to base logical arguments coming, as we do, out of the cerebrally Greek tradition. So I do not base my disapproval of schism on sentimentality or anything like it. Instead, pure utilitarianism drives me as I take the Hegelian route to which I alluded when I said that dissenters are the lifeblood of any organization. It is certainly true, and Christians and Darwinians can both agree, that we move towards perfection always, never reaching it, always striving. The impetus to strive (the urge to synthesize) comes from the confrontation of ideas, or, as Hegel put it, the nexus at which thesis meets antithesis. This is the Hegelian dialectic. To my mind, it makes sense. If whenever any person has a good but controversial idea they move on with a small cadre of like minded revolutionaries to inhabit a separate hermetically sealed conceptual chamber, no one benefits from the synthesis that occurs when disagreeing people sit down to work their shit out. It should be said that I think many people have some things right, and that no one has everything right. That's probably my main unstated premise. But now it's stated. By the way, I also have a sentimentalist argument, but I save that for the women. Just kidding. But I do have a sentimentalist argument.
Also, I have been drinking whiskey and watching Ricki Lake give birth for the last 2 hours.

"Would christians with differing views of liturgy, baptism, and sacraments be excluded from xmin?"

So looking at this closer ... as with other Christian denominations, admission to Communion is the de facto in-or-out. XMin effectively sets three "hard" requirements here: baptism, affiliation with an XMin household, and participation in XMin worship. Within the context of Christianity as a whole, dropping the first requirement would be very drastic. I think it has to stand. The interesting thing is that the latter two--affiliation and worship--are fulfilled precisely by participating in Communion. In other words, assuming baptism, participation in XMin Communion is self-validating.

There are so many question I would have about xmin, were I to take it seriously as a denomination or, more it seems, a patch for one's choir robe.

But I would point out that xmin seems to assume the Christian religious community at large (or is it Anglicans? is the distinction important?) is primarily interested in dropping the requirements for being Christian.

Ok, so I'll try to convince you: Faithfulness and Problem Solving are the heart of XMin for me. Faithfulness addresses "household, neighborhood, work, and other" relationships. The latter three are all outside of XMin (and the first is just the people you live with). XMin adherents are humans before they are XMin adherents. Likewise, Problem Solving is broad, encompassing humanity's problems, to be solved as a human with the rest of humanity. Am I convincing you? Does this need to be clearer in the document?

XMin is, first of all, an attempt to scratch my own religious itch. I'd be willing to collaborate with people with a similar itch, and I don't mind hashing it through with skeptics. But I don't really care about any "community at large."

I've committed to the Rule of Life, but until someone commits to the whole thing, most of this is hot air.

Faithfulness and Problem Solving are so not the province of a minimalism religion. They imply (but are not symbolic of) so many other issues that a minimalist religion -- were it sincerely interested in asking one human or human family to join its ranks in person, rather than in the form of an online questionaire -- would seek to encapsulate (xmin interestingly refuses to touch this), or shift focus from.

You're trying to tell me that I can have the best things religion has to offer by refusing almost all of them. In the words of Ronnie Dobbs, "You're trying to shit in my mouth and call it a sundae."

You said, '...what is the organization? I think the organization is humanity. Even the Amish are in fact a part of culture, and XMin is much more engaged. There is no "hermetically sealed conceptual chamber."' 

Distinguishing the religious community at large (which has provided tangibleness to your theological venture) from humanity may be a good illustration of scale and boundary, but it doesn't help me much.

But also ... XMin defines little at the structural level because the emphasis is interpersonal. In XMin, all of the meaty, demanding religious stuff happens face to face, in a smoky attic, or a well-appointed den. Which is where it happens anyway; XMin just dispenses with most of the formal bullshit. For the defining document to be anemic is a kudos. But again, that leaves XMin waiting to be realized before it can be fully judged.

I'll backpedal and say I don't care about impressing or swaying any community at large. I care about culture, humanity, and subcultures. I like that there is a giant mish-mash of Christian cultures that basically get me off the hook from having to define anything, cause everything is already defined. XMin is a little coracle for sailing the seas of culture. It's in the mix with everything else (or would be if anyone was XMin).

Christianity wants to be defined, and hierarchically defined. Christians want that too. They like to know they're in a church, that that's what they've chosen. They don't want to be thrown out of a church they've accepted on their own terms, or alternately blitzkreiged by a book of Common Prayer in someone's living room when they were just trying to hang out. 

xmin muddles together a lot of complex concepts under the guise of minimalism. It trivializes, I think, membership. It tell me membership isn't necessary, and then asks things of me.
If you want Christianity to be defined and hierarchical then XMin is not for you. I am interested in a decentralized Christianity.

As a Christian, I should want my actions to supercede what people assume of my faith. I should want my religious agency, a small part of an immense effort, to be drawn in bold lineaments that defy the preconception of my religion, which is deservedly awful. I can't throw it away; I have to suffer to rework it.

The sea of culture is meant to be boated or swum. It doesn't mean that you won't end up flotsam, but anything else surely will.
Decentralized Christianity: any anchorite who demands an audience.

Could you be an adherent of xmin without knowing you were or proclaiming fealty? I could possibly be into that. But I get hung up on your use of the term "denomination". An actual minimalistic conception of Christianity would not, I think, require any sort of pledge of exclusivity or association.
To minimalize Christianity would be to include a lot more people. That's the value that I would see in it and that's what my own xmin looks like.

Left to itself, form follows function. The accretion of formality to religion is as old as religion. Form is not bullshit. Some instances of form may be bullshit in that they don't necessarily have to look the way they do (could look like something else entirely), but there has to be something there. If there didn't, I don't think it would be there.

And if you think that xmin has dispensed with formality you are crazy.
I should also mention that I like the idea of xmin.

In that sense, xmin is an attempt to saddle friendship, neighborhood or community with further definition they might not want or need.

I think of it as: everyone I know, in Pittsburgh, primarily, and beyond, is a person possessing religious beliefs both social and personal. I would not, for one moment, associate the character of the person, how much I like them, how much they factor into my life, with those social and personal religious attributes -- no matter how much they are implied. Nor would I expect that consideration from them. We will work it out, but I don't need an e-manifesto to tell me how to do that.

XMin defines XMin. What does it say about friends, neighbors, and communities other than that XMin adherents try to be good friends, neighbors, and citizens? Catholicism has a whole lot more to say, I think ...

Here's how I think that it works (and has always worked):

-If enough people say "<action> is fine," then to say "<action> is not fine" becomes wrong, false.  People may then want to say "we prohibit <activity>" but they don't because it's wrong.  "Wrong" means that they sufficiently get in trouble, or they feel embarassed, or they are called bigots, or assholes.  "What people think" defines right and wrong.

-To what degree they are justified in trying to retain the thing (by fighting permission of <action>) is determined by how wrong it is, i.e. how badly it feels and appears to do so.  They are justified resisting permission of <action> in whatever degree it is not "wrong" to do so.  Justification rises from "what people think."

-There is no other type of justification.  What one might consider justification from God is actually justification from "what people think" about God.  Justification only means "what people think."  

-The reason that a person resists permitting <action> is the perception that to permit <action> creates a danger to their self and group.  So they resist.  

-There is only one difference between Heroes and Unholy Bigots, then, as there is only one source of justification:  "what people think."  

-This cannot be disputed.  The only way to dispute this is to say what one thinks.

-The feeling of repugnance that one has for <action>, say, or <action>, deceptively causes one to think that there is a system of justification outside of "what people think."  But, do not forget History.  Repugnance is learned.  

-This is how today's Hero is tommorrow's Unholy Bigot, or vice versa.  Or Bigot, Hero, Bigot, and back again...

-The most common pattern is that "regular" people become bigots as "what people think" shifts.

-It is thought that decisions are made by proceeding from evidence, through correct thinking and to correct decision.  It never has worked this way.  People start with decision and then support it with evidence and correct thinking.  When one is born one is floating in the center of the ocean, wet, committed, and without any reference.  Apologetics is the business of using your evidence and correct thinking in the presence of someone else using theirs.   Thinking of decision making this way is as "true" as the old model, and much more helpful, i.e. it leads to less killing.

-When decision comes to an individual it is experienced as a gain in freedom.  Either by the addition or subtraction of a restriction.

~~


To relate this all to the church:

- The church will, and therefore should, change to keep itself adequately aligned with "what people think."
- The church goes more slowly than other institutions.  I think that it should. (I guess)


- In the church it is playing badly to resist movement of any kind.  You alienate large groups within.
- In the church it is playing badly to move too rapidly.  You alienate a large groups within.

I guess that one way to put the question might be "how fast?"

Bonhoeffer's critique of ethics results in a picture of an Aristotelian ethic that is Christological in expression, i.e., it shares much in common with a character-oriented morality, and at the same time it rests firmly on his Christology. For Bonhoeffer, the foundation of ethical behavior is how the reality of the world and how the reality of God are reconciled in the reality of Christ (Ethics, p. 198). To share in Christ's reality is to become a responsible person, a person who performs actions in accordance with reality and the fulfilled will of God (Ethics, p.224). There are two guides for determining the will of God in any concrete situation: 1) the need of one's neighbor, and 2) the model of Jesus of Nazareth. There are no other guides, since Bonhoeffer denies that we can have knowledge of good and evil (Ethics, p.231). There is no moral certainty in this world. There is no justification in advance for our conduct. Ultimately all actions must be delivered up to God for judgment, and no one can escape reliance upon God's mercy and grace. "Before God self-justification is quite simply sin" (Ethics, p.167).

From here: http://www.iep.utm.edu/b/bonhoeff.htm#H2

The basic, most important, point in "Ethics" is best described as a condemnation of judgment of the Other because it is by that same judgment that the "Ethicist" attempts to sanctify themselves (an act which can only be done by Jesus Christ). It is more than useless, it is sinful, to say what others should be doing. The only purpose for that kind of performative statement is to establish that the speaker is Justified. Chad, I hear you talking about "voluntarism" but you are just using different words to prescribe. You are voluntarily adopting a nonarbitrary lifestyle because you think that it constitutes "right living." You don't think that it doesn't matter. You think that it matters. And, furthermore, you are seeking to justify yourself.

I am currently working towards a Bonhoefferian way of being Catholic in the world. It is not easy.

So many wonderful ideas in Bonhoeffer. Another one from the same link:

Furthermore, the sole guide for acting in accordance with this reality is the model of Jesus' selfless behavior in the New Testament. There are numerous dimensions to this model. First and foremost, your action can in no way be intended to reflect back on you, your character, or your reputation. You must, for the sake of the moment, unreservedly surrender all self-directed wishes and desires (Ethics, p.232). It is the other, another person, that is the focus of attention, and not yourself. In ethical action, the left hand really must be unaware of what the right hand is doing if the right hand is to do anything ethical. If not, your so-called good action becomes contaminated and its moral nature altered.

"Jesus refuses to see the world in these terms. He lightly, almost cavalierly, casts aside many of the legal distinctions the Pharisee labors to maintain. He bids his disciples to eat on the Sabbath, even though starvation is hardly in question. He heals a woman on the Sabbath, although after eighteen years of illness she could seemingly wait a few more hours. Jesus exhibits a freedom from the law in everything he does, but nothing he does suggests all things are possible. There is nothing arbitrary about his behavior. There is, however, a simplicity and clarity. Unlike the Pharisee, he is unconcerned with the goodness or badness of those he helps, unconcerned with the personal moral worth of those he meets, talks to, dines with, or heals. He is concerned solely and entirely with the well being of another. He exhibits no other concern. He is the paradigm of selfless action, and the exact opposite of the Pharisee, whose every gesture is fundamentally self-reflective."

What I think is going on here is that we have different concerns.

Mark, I think you are concerned with stripping some of the social accretions off of Racism by defining it in as basic a way as possible. I think that is an interesting idea but I'm a little confused as to why you would want to do this to the exclusion of a more complex view of Racism, because...

I see Racism as a complex problem. To describe it as "Unkindness at the interpersonal level" seems to me to be an oversimplification of the problem. When a problem is oversimplified the difficulty of its solution is underestimated.

But maybe our difference is Scope. You seem to be interested in the narrow scope of the problem of racism. I suppose I would agree that <discrete instances of racism> = <unkindness at the interpersonal level>.

But that Scope isn't broad enough for me, really. That's not what I'm talking about when I talk about Racism. I am talking about a huge class of people <racists> who are unkind in a specific way towards a specific group of people. To describe the thing they do as "unkindness" seems to me almost to imply that the similarities between their actions are almost only coincidental.

"Indeed, the only consistent predictor was fame — and it was an inverse relationship. The more famous experts did worse than unknown ones. That had to do with a fault in the media. Talent bookers for television shows and reporters tended to call up experts who provided strong, coherent points of view, who saw things in blacks and whites. People who shouted — like, yes, Jim Cramer!

Mr. Tetlock called experts such as these the “hedgehogs,” after a famous distinction by the late Sir Isaiah Berlin (my favorite philosopher) between hedgehogs and foxes. Hedgehogs tend to have a focused worldview, an ideological leaning, strong convictions; foxes are more cautious, more centrist, more likely to adjust their views, more pragmatic, more prone to self-doubt, more inclined to see complexity and nuance. And it turns out that while foxes don’t give great sound-bites, they are far more likely to get things right.

This was the distinction that mattered most among the forecasters, not whether they had expertise. Over all, the foxes did significantly better, both in areas they knew well and in areas they didn’t. "

Lastly, I got a lot out of this conversation.

Not success.
Granted, I have a high bar for attributing "success."
And I think, honestly, that I want you to have success probably as much as you do. It is the thing I want the most, but in circa 45 at bats I haven't come close.

You managed to find a person of reasonable intelligence who was not (at least primarily) looking for cybersex. Remarkable but also not (should not be) remarkable.

This person does not know who Joseph Campbell is. That is prima facie evidence that this person is not ready to have the kind of conversation from which either of you could benefit. I don't think I am being "Western Canon centric" here--if a person was honestly interested enough in what you are talking about here, they would have sought out relevant sources and found J. Campbell. Or at least heard about it (him) in passing. This is not a high bar. Basic knowledge of the existence of Joseph Campbell is fucking relevant. I don't want to be an asshole (may be regardless), but a conversation about comparative religion with someone who has never heard of Joseph Campbell is suspect as to its "value-addedness". 

Which leads me to my second point: You do most of the talking. His responses are intelligent, but they are not informed. That is a crucial distinction, I think. This person is a smart person (or at least a person with basic social and linguistic decoding skills) who has chosen to apply their skills to the dialogue with which you have presented them.

All this person has provided you with is a venue for a semi-subsidized monologue. There's no give and take. That is (one of the few?) the only thing I care about: capable agents battling it out in the realm of ideas. If that isn't happening, I'm really not interested.

I'm not trying to come down on you Chad. I think you do some really great work with thinking (the highest pursuit, I think), but I'm trying to express what I see as a fundamental weakness in Omegle. I have tried it. I have really wanted it to be something special. But I have found it to be seriously lacking. Your exchange with this person has been much, much better than anything I have managed to accomplish. But I think it still fails. It pales in comparison to talking, face to face, with a person I know and trust. I would rather talk to Chad than to anyone I would ever happen to find on Omegle. Omegle just seems like a diversion and a waste of time to me.

Also interesting (for me):

"The question then becomes: What shapes moral emotions in the first place? The answer has long been evolution, but in recent years there’s an increasing appreciation that evolution isn’t just about competition. It’s also about cooperation within groups. Like bees, humans have long lived or died based on their ability to divide labor, help each other and stand together in the face of common threats. Many of our moral emotions and intuitions reflect that history. We don’t just care about our individual rights, or even the rights of other individuals. We also care about loyalty, respect, traditions, religions. We are all the descendants of successful cooperators.

The first nice thing about this evolutionary approach to morality is that it emphasizes the social nature of moral intuition. People are not discrete units coolly formulating moral arguments. They link themselves together into communities and networks of mutual influence."
I think I already knew this. I think this goes to what we were talking about, Rick, re:in-group identification.

Rupert Sheldrake stabs at this in The Presence of the Past. 

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rupert_Sheldrake#The_Presence_of_the_Past

His research did not match up to his thought and he was more or less marginalized for it.

Science is not quite ready to inquire who or what rides human beings. Thus, attempts are both magical and philosophical, in the sense that they consist of little more than a set of words that are to describe our nature.
To be explicit, human nature is the province of philosophy. That the words do not resemble what they are trying to say is irrelevant. They're all we got right now.
I would have thought that his marginalization would have resulted from his being a complete and utter quack.

Ok. This is good. Because Sheldrake wasn't always a quack.

Before, he was a respected biochemist doing funded research. After, he is a fringy, um, resonance theorist?

So either he got old/bored and lost his marbles, or he switched his collateral  as, Chad was fond of saying, did Bono. 

The point is that before, he was marginal. After, I know who he is, and am considering what he says. He has a place on my ratty Pittsburgh bookshelf. If his long shot of a resonance field exists, he has made himself a wavelength in one.

The problem may be that he is passing himself off as a scientist, instead of a former-scientist-cum-metaphysical-revelator. Everyone in that business is a quack unfortunately, unless they're in the canon.

(I'd add that this plasticity of implication is applied daily in quantum structure, and no one bats an eyelash. They do seem to be working a bit harder than Sheldrake, whose experiments seem to be afterthought. Re:"The End of Philosophy")

There's no simple, or elegant, answer as to who rides us, to what degree and for how long. Have you read any Sheldrake, Wayne?

'If Sheldrake sounds like a crackpot, he is. But delightfully so. Mad scientists are a thing of the past. Sheldrake makes an off-the-cuff comment that he discovered from old radar records that the speed of light slowed during the 1940s. Then he points out that it was Francis Bacon who believed scientists should be the new priesthood. And that's how science has functioned ever since -- most of our modern priests are "busy doing genetic research for Monsanto." Indeed, the former editor of Nature, John Maddox -- "the 'pope of science,'" Sheldrake laughs -- called Sheldrake a "lapsed Jesuit attacking the church of science." Maddox advocated literally burning Sheldrake's books as heresy, yelling, "He deserves to be condemned for the exact same reasons the pope condemned Galileo."

'...After being urged for years to find more "empirical evidence" of morphic fields, he became a Captain Kangaroo of sorts, encouraging hundreds of schoolkids worldwide to document how the family pet tuned into morphic fields. He's collected irrefutable evidence that Lassie almost always knows when her master is returning home. Spot can sense forthcoming epileptic attacks. Rover sniffs out cancer. Canines even forecast earthquakes. "In China, the government monitors earthquakes by dogs," Sheldrake says. "But when I ran this by the American insurance industry, they said, 'You know, you could maybe save lives with earthquake-sensing dogs, but we're a general insurance company. Go talk to the life insurance people.'"

'In 1996, Sheldrake paused in his dogged research to hook up with renegade priest Matthew Fox and hold public discourses on God (which is you-know-what spelled backward). After all, the Almighty seems to be where the larger implications of morphic resonance head. What if morphic resonance encompasses the narrative direction of our lives? Perhaps destiny is more than just some literary conceit. Maybe karma is not only instant, but real as well. Perhaps we can even actually influence God herself as easily as chicks can stop random-movement robots.

'Ah. These ideas just bounce off Sheldrake. He doesn't bite. After all, his God is, well, British. "I belong to the Church of England," he says. He talks about his beliefs, and he buys the whole thing -- Father, Son, Holy Ghost. Rupert Sheldrake is only a heretic in the Church of Science.

'But in the end, Sheldrake successfully defends the profundity of his current animal work. "The thing about dogs," he says, "although some people might think this is trivial from a scientific point of view, it's actually exactly the opposite. Science believes animals and plants are all just unconscious automatons. The whole of nature is unconscious except for human beings. We're the only smart guys in the whole universe and somehow figured out how everything works. And that means through science we can manipulate nature and improve products for corporations."'

A five-fold distinction comes to mind:

  1. Miracles of nature
  2. Miracles of healing (special case of #1)
  3. Miracles of raising the dead 
(special case of #2)
  4. Miracles of psychology (i.e., prayer)
  5. Miracles of the mundane (e.g., my children)

The last is the easy one, but it actually gives insight into the others. We are comfortable with the application of the term to the degree that the matter is also explicable in "natural" terms. Hence efforts like:

  http://www.freerepublic.com/focus/f-news/1070908/posts
  http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/hub/A449345

My general sentiments regarding 1-3:

  - it's a soup
  - most of these miracles (in the Bible and out) didn't happen
  - most of the rest are embellished
  - the only one I actually care about is the Resurrection

#4 is where the question mark is for me. I'm not even sure what it's supposed to mean.

I think that what it boils down to (and this is a key part of my conception of social reality): People who have an advantage *really* want to keep that advantage, and their social interactions are invariably guided by an unconsciously generated algorithm (particle swarm optimization) that solves the following problem: what is the best possible method to perpetuate the advantage that I enjoy. 

The life that should be lived according to this algorithm is like the cake. The ethic system that a person uses to justify the behavior required by this algorithm is like the icing--it conforms to the surface of the cake and is very sticky--even when the icing shouldn't stick (because the cake to which it is being applied is completely upside down, e.g. "turn the other cheek" vs. "lynch some black people"), it does, and people don't really seem to mind the inconsistency, because they don't really *care* about the icing. It's the cake, stupid.

So, it should not be surprising that people who have an advantage and will do anything to maintain that advantage would devalue entire classes of people if doing so would help to maintain their advantage, correct?

And that is what I propose to be the case: devaluing these classes of people (based on ethnicity, race, whatever) serves a *very* important role in perpetuating the status quo, an objective that is very near and dear to the heart of the advantaged classes.

Here is why: the advantage enjoyed by the Haters would be diminished if the disadvantaged were shown to deserve an equal share of God's Good Earth. So, naturally, the best decision is to show that they do NOT deserve an equal share of God's Good Earth. Obviously, characteristics like skin color do not *actually* matter--at the individual level these are arbitrary genetic codings that at the global level have happened to correlate over time and through cultural accident/wars/Machiavellian race promotion (eugenics, genocide), with socio-economic disadvantage--what matters is that the people who happen to have skin color X are disadvantaged, and their disadvantage is the Haters' advantage, so the Haters' algorithm directs them to perpetuate these disadvantaged people in order to perpetuate the Haters' advantage. So, the Haters dehumanize them.

It makes sense, really.

Here's a thought exercise that just popped into my head: think of racism (white supremacy, whatever) like unemployment.

Everyone knows that unemployment is bad (of course especially at the individual level). But, many economists never want to see the unemployment rate drop too low, because inflation would skyrocket. Unemployment is a release valve for inflation. Look it up. It's true.

Now, perhaps the racism that Rick is asking about is, as I said, a manifestation of the Advantaged following their algorithm. The algorithm is complex. It takes many variables into account. It is an algorithm, after all, not a fucking arithmetic problem.

This algorithm, for reasons unknown to you or I or probably anyone, has factored lots of shit into its rules. Such as: increasing education levels among all classes of people, increasing access to information, increasing racial diversity in developed countries, etc.

So, the algorithm is like any optimization routine--it has to find the best possible solution for the given problem: *maximizing* the perpetuation of the advantage enjoyed by the Advantaged. It can't just *perpetuate" it--that would imply a perfect solution. But the solution can't be perfect, because it is susceptible to degradation over time given the flexible contours of the space in which the problem exists (society and the distribution of wealth).

Anyway, so the algorithm has determined the behaviors that will best serve the objective of the Advantaged. Those are the behaviors that we are seeing. We see racism in politics (but not as much as 30 years ago, because the algorithm is adapting to a changing context--the variables are shifting--more expressions of racism (more Pat Buchanans) would actually result in *less* advantage. But, right now, anyway, 1 Pat Buchanan is the optimal number of Pat Buchanans for the optimization of advantage perpetuation.

Racism is alive and well, it just has a slow, calculated leak.

Calling Pat Buchanan a white supremacist (or something like a white supremacist) seems a bit of a leap in logic. That article is a doozy, but place it in any kind of context.

Is anyone with a complex, public conception of race which is not terror-stricken at every tier of its explication to be considered racist/<group> supremacist? 

Or: will we ever be comfortable with the tone/appellations of any racial dialogue?

I can't claim to fully understand the Wayno's posts on advantage perpetuation. I do see algorithms in political development -- ones we must pass over in silence, and simpler ones written by people who act and compiled for the benefit of people who listen. (Pat Buchanan is posturing for the latter, and flaring his feathers wide because he has been deserted by rivals.) But it doesn't help me to look at racial prejudice as an apparition of Advantaged people maintaining their status quo. 

By that model, the apparitions may never end. Also, this hate is currently moving on all available vectors. I have problems differentiating advantaged-on-déclasse racism from other kinds. It all seems equally viable: as a tonic to the poor (a tonic to a great many more, appealing perhaps to the same regions of executive function that religion does); a wave to buffet the middle class; a trivial factor to the rich.

I'd argue the affluent are disinterested in race and need not to worry where it intersects with class. Those interested in human affairs will necessarily speak to their own apparent cultural designations.

(I'm also interested in the capacity of righteousness available to the racially aware young person -- mainly, that they are fit to lecture their elders on anything from history to culture.)

This is a great example of Wikipedia sacrificing Knowledge for "knowledge" by presenting us with an undifferentiated mass of sentences. Ugh, ack. Einstein's own introduction to relativity is much more lucid. Regarding the Lorentz transformation, the bottom line comes at the end of Appendix II (p. 122 in the 15th edition): "We can regard Minkowski's 'world' in a formal manner as a four-dimensional Euclidean space (with imaginary time co-ordinate); the Lorentz transformation corresponds to a 'rotation' of the co-ordinate system in the four-dimensional 'world'." In other words, we have mathematicians building on one another's work to model our Universe: Euclid -> Lorentz -> Minkowski -> Einstein The system of equations developed by Lorentz, when one zooms out a level (to Minkowski's frame), turn out to describe a rotation in four dimensions. Einstein zooms out further and applies Minkowski's obtuse four-dimensionalism to space-time. The moves here are simple and gorgeous, but you'd never know it from Wikipedia. P.S.
