But what about the guy parading around town in the middle of the chaos, actually hoisting the Cup?

That would be Pittsburgh native Marco Gruelle, who was one of six people taking part in the hilarious counter-protest. Gruelle said it was his friend, Daniel Mross, who was responsible for coming up with the idea to turn the G-20 into a re-make of the Stanley Cup celebration from this past June.

"We were very afraid it (the G-20) was going to put Pittsburgh in a bad light," said Gruelle. "Everybody was walking around on eggshells for the past two weeks with all the police, and protesters, and military, and this and that, and we were afraid some schmucks were going to come in and put a bad face on Pittsburgh and, well, we weren't going to let that happen. We figured the best way to do that, and the most effective way that's going to get our point across and still make people laugh, was to, you know ... well ... Let's Go Pens."

When the Cup made its first appearance on live TV, it appeared to leave protesters confused, and, for a brief moment, somewhat disoriented. News reporters and policemen dressed as stormtroopers struggled to keep a straight face and did everything they could not to laugh. 

"The reaction we got from everybody was great," said Gruelle. "When we were walking up the street every single person beeped their horn and had a great time with it."

"The protesters didn't know what to do at first. You know, sometimes when you do something like that they might get angry. There were some blocks where people were happy and just hanging out, there might have been some other blocks that had people getting angry and starting to throw stones. On those blocks we kind of actually defused the situation. Basically, we showed Pittsburgh what we are: the City of Champions."

I hereby ratify and adopt the blag post as my official position, with the following rider excerpted from an email I just sent to a friend:

-----

They hope, I think unrealistically, that it will become the archetypal first iteration of a next generation of Internet-based communication, the first of its kind that manages to effectively and purposefully eschew any disadvantageous resemblance to the analog technologies of yesteryear (and the attendant, incongruous constraints that result from the awkward retrofitting of those paradigms onto the Internet's digital backbone). In a nut, they want to replace email+chat+shared documents+everything else with something new that accomplishes all of the objectives of these modalities but, unlike these, has no corollary to the pre-Internet epoch

The Google seems to think that this thing is the "next big thing" in a way that nothing else yet has been.

Of course they hope for world domination. But, in this instance, they've publicly expressed as much more so than for anything I can recall.

i went to public school.  then in school, i studied school systems.  it's tough to generalize about public school efficacy vs. private or charter or home-based...cause the school climates can vary a lot and learners vary a lot....

i have to say, i hated my high school.  it was clicky, superficial, exclusionary, terrifying, and wields an insane amount of power in socializing adolescents and preparing them for adulthood.  that being said, critical distance from it has served me well.  and to be fair, many people had positive experiences in public schools.   my distillation:  schools are successful insofar as they connect with their communities, make efforts to be inclusive, and remain free of as many forms of interpersonal harassment as possible.  

literacy is essential, too, i think.  if people can read and understand, they can educate themselves.  school as a social institution is often unnecessary in certain respects....  But this gets tricky, cause social contact is a great form of education....

I remember some great director or another describing film school as "30% very useful information, which you will need to undo the other 70%." (A paraphrase.)

That's how I see public schooling. (I am admittedly skeptical of most extensions of the state, but this foray into education seems an especially perilous one.) I'm surprised at how parents seem hesitant to really interact with the system, as they own it. They evince powerlessness and can then grumble about it, or alternately start a fund for private schooling.

I'm also torn between the desire for my child to acquire as much social skill as possible, and to spare them the bizarre office reality of public school, where the objectives and rewards seem more like measures than realities.

So IRT match_fresh's comments:

1. The problem of reading is relatively easy: have kids read at a young age. Er, make them. The problem of writing: no comment.

2. I agree that an analysis of schools by type is further clouded by their variance under an avertible curriculum. There are excellent public schools, misguided private ones -- hell, homeschooling can be anything. I've thought and read for thousands of hours on the topic, participated in several systems, and am yet uncertain about how to proceed.

3. I do want my kids to be exposed to the cliquish, exclusionary and terrifying elements of high school. And  I want them to be equipped to deal with it. (I reserve the right to reverse this position upon viewing my first-born.)

love the 30% - 70% distinction.   totally!  i mean, how many grads needs to know factorials, or how to write ionic compounds correctly?  At the same time, I have to admit, they came to me at such a young age, I'm almost nostalgic about this stuff at this point.  When I see them again during these tutoring sessions, it's kinda like looking at pictures of our old house in autumn.  its just warm and fuzzy to remember it all.  potassium phosphate, magnesium sulfite, lithium chloride....mamma mia!  

IRT your comment on parents - i think there are a lot of reasons parents don't interact with it.  "they schools" names a lot of important reasons, and there are others.  curriculum is often boring and irrelevant to students.  parents opinions are not collected or appropriately represented by school boards, who wield a big influence on school procedures.  teachers favor certain kids over others, and students know this.  teachers have "bad days," and don't take the time to listen to students concerns.  students then tell their parents about problems in their classes.  administrators and teachers in the school often react defensively or half-heartedly, because the "reputation" of the school is more important than the school's actual quality.  And of course, finally, many schools operate in a history of profoundly racist policies and procedures, a fact any black or brown person is viscerally aware of both historically and on a daily basis in their day to day dealings in American society.     

so from my point of view, it is the responsibility of parents to help their kids learn and to encourage their learning, and many kids aren't motivated because parents are not supporting their kid's learning processes in productive ways.  And it is also the responsibility of school leadership to communicate to parents that their views and opinions matter in the school.   if they don't, parents are wise not to waste their time interacting with the school.   

IRT number 3: i hear you on this point, and I think people learn forms of resilience through experiences with tough situations. and also, it depends how we define "terrifying" and how we define "deal with it."  I'm guessing we are on the same page with this point.  In terms of a school climate, I would want my kid to be protected from forms of social dysfunction as much as possible.  things like physical violence, ongoing ridicule about his/her language or clothing or beliefs, racist or sexist or ethnically prejudiced discourses, or anything else that might interfere with his/her utilization of the learning tools the school intends to provide.

that's all i got for now.  feeling tired.  gonna listen to some music and go to bed early.  mmmmmm....sleepytime in the western world.  ciao!

here's a little story for ya'll.  

I went to Westhill High School in Syracuse, NY.  A block down from Westhill there was an outdoor shopping area called Western Lights.  It's got a K-Mart, a supermarket, a local shoe store, McDonald's, and BK.  I used to ride my skateboard from my house to school, then after school, I'd ride it down the block to Western Lights.  80% of the shoppers of Western Lights (again, a BLOCK from my high school) were black.  NONE (not even ONE) of them went to my high school.  this was the early 90's, and it was the northern version of race segregation-by-carefully-sketching-district boundaries (which is still happening currently, btw)  

Here's another quick story:  

My professor Gloria (who was as black as Michele Obama at midnight) was called a nigger by a carload of white people while she was walking from her office to her car last fall.  

And another comes to mind: 

There's no way my Italian, uneducated, recently arrived grandmother would've gotten a job at the Dodgeville Slipper Factory in upstate NY if she was black.  They didn't hire black people.   

Oh, somebody stop me, I got ANOTHER one.  Sorry.  

Just went to a law conference at Harvard the other day, put on by Charles Ogletree through the Charles Hamilton Center.  Heard a lotta statistics.  One of them comes to mind.  Black men are being executed at a 10-1 ratio to white men in our justice system.   Yikes.  

Yeah, we need some race reconciliation, and it's no cheap cliche to say it either.

here's a quick response, IRT to "every religion has a sacred text" 

I think every critique utilizes tools of thought to analyze a discourse.  "Every religion has a sacred text" reflects a tool I've seen many people use.  It involves attempting to debunk or refute an argument by saying that he/she does it too.  I see some truth in this, so I don't mean to simply counterattack it.  But I would rather utilize a thought tool that doesn't try to assume or appropriate the other person's discourse.  Rather, I'm concerned about what Roth says and how he says it, not with some proposed set of group beliefs about people that may or may not adhere to the themes of his work.  What's the point of creating a "group conception" and then attacking it?  

This approach doesn't help me learn anything.

(As a follow-up to a conversation with Rick)

I do not subscribe to every or even many of the positions in the GQ article (The Bitch is Back, post 1053), and my own recent thoughts on Ayn Rand predate my reading of it by at least 3 weeks, as shown by my comment on post 1005:

"...extending like a haughty monad-cón-gonad out of the ethereal nothingness of Ayn Rand's architectural blueprint of an imagination."

http://dev.music.flanderous.com/part/1005

I agree that the GQ article unnecessarily vituperates people who identify Ayn Rand as a good or even favorite author. As we discussed, this class of persons includes persons you and I both know to be of sound mind and good character. I myself at one time considered The Fountainhead to be a very good book if not one of my favorites, and I do not think that I was any less virtuous at that time than at this time.

But, having duly educated myself on the specifics of Ayn Rand's philosoph, I find that it offends my conscience perhaps more so than any other philosophy I can imagine existing. I mean, the woman despises *altruism* and wants weak people to die. Pluralism be damned, that does NOT jive with my vision of how people should conduct their intellectual/spiritual lives.

So, given that I prescriptively assert that Rand's philosophy *should* be universally repugnant, and given that she intended her novels to serve primarily as vehicles for the promulgation of this philosophy (as instantiated by John Galt's 65-page-long speech/lecture), I cannot in good conscience "be okay" with anyone actually *liking* these novels, regardless of who the person is.

I would not (and do not) think ill of a person simply because they like or even love Ayn Rand's novels, but I would certainly appreciate the opportunity to explain to them my very good reasons for thinking that they should not (which also include, I might add, an extreme dearth of stylistic virtue/lyricism/character complexity/plot profluence/etc.)

Which traditions would you prefer?

well, i realize now this opens up a big world of ideas for me.  i have a lot of thoughts on it, so in my thoughts I'm trying to pare it down so that it won't turn out to be some didactic essay on what i think about traditions.  i guess to put it concisely - the suit is something that evolved throughout europe, and the ones we commonly wear in the states (and now accross the world) have come to symbolize power and authority.  and i'm never comfortable with symbols of power and authority, especially when they conceal hypocrisy, manipulation, violent behavior, and professional forms of hierarchy.  in a word, i don't like it when people act superior to other people, and i think the suit often sends this kind of message to others.  my preference is for the opposite - I want to convey warmth and generosity and openness with my clothing.  i just don't prefer aristocratic or hierarchical traditions, and the suit is a symbol - a powerful symbol - of those.  (and i should add, i don't think this is related specifically to english, or spanish, or italian people per se, but suits come from european aristocratic traditions, and these are traditions i'm not comfortable perpetuating or supporting or representing. and finally, i don't think a suit as a symbol automatically makes a person "evil" or "power hungry" or whatever.  the tension for me is the historical context of the suit, and what the suit has become as a symbol in professional settings, and the way it structures authority and power in culture and - specifically - in professional settings),  

thanks for reading my thoughts.  i'd love to hear yours.  what do you think/feel?  would love to hear some feedback on this.   i realize it opens up big issues...but hey, i kinda like big issues....

The following are some thoughts I had after reading Chad's Watchtower:

One thing (well, 3 things) about evangelical protestants (including even an Anglican or two, present company excluded) at which I take umbrage: 1) No or little respect for tradition and the authority thereof, 2) No or not much of a sense of propriety or self-restraint, and 3) No or at least no apparent comprehension of the absurd ridiculousness of describing the Divine and the religious life with an unending cacophany of neologisms and transitory cultural metaphors derived primarily from the rampant stupidity of the mass media.

This third one troubles me the most, because the language you use to describe a thing changes your understanding of the thing. If one decides to adopt new words or fashion new (and often stupid) analogies to describe a thing that has been around for a very long time, one should realize what one is doing, the ramifications of that thing, and whether any good is served.

I prefer the liturgical approach to communal worship because stupid people with good intentions can't come in and try to describe the Gospel in a way that is even *better* (more culturally relevant, easier for mass media troglodytes to digest) than the way it is described in the goddamn effing Bible itself. Of course, their description sucks, it relegates the Divine to second chair in an analogy based on the tv show Lost, and it contaminates the understanding of the Divine for everyone who hears it and identifies with, perhaps, the cultural reference.

Now, I am not saying that this is what Chad is doing. I've said, and still believe, that Chad does good work. There is a difference between the purposeful pursuit of a greater understanding of the Divine or some part thereof, e.g. The Gospel, and rebranding it in a way that fundamentally changes it, maybe because you think it will get more kids to the altar call at church camp.

Except those kids are now "believing" (i.e. experiencing a culturally mediated identification with) in a bizarre Cultural Analogue Jesus Who Came So That No One Would Ever Be Voted Off The Island, or whatever most recent poetic liberty youth pastor/heretic Greg Johnson dreamt up last week.

here's an experience i had one morning.  i walked from my apartment to Espresso Royale to get coffee and a bagel.  i sat there, and while i was eating, noticed that there were surveillance cameras in the coffee shop.  i was being videotaped while eating breakfast and drinking coffee.  i wondered about the influence of the "threat" of terrorism on the presence of these cameras.  i wondered about why i was being recorded sipping my morning coffee.  i wondered about privacy rights.

At this time I'd like to link an article:  

http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/24/AR2009072402090.html

And to say a couple things.

I wish that I used "underdeveloped" rather than "poor" in the first statement.  Poverty doesn't get it quite, it's really a whole bunch of things.  Money is only one thing.  However, the concentration principle applies to them all.  (We should probably investigate this more fully.)

And for the second statement, "poor" is also off the mark.  I was trying to indicate a racism which is, to once again use Shelby Steele language, a "barrier to black advancment."   

Shelby Steele, in the article that I linked, says that racism is not a significant barrier to black advancement.  I read that last night and I've wondered a lot about all of the possible meanings of his claim, as well as the possible reactions from a person like me.

The very end of that article:

"But fortunately race relations in America are not much driven by the courts. We argue over affirmative action and disparate impact because we don't know how to talk about our most profound racial problem: the lack of developmental parity between blacks and whites. Today a certain contradiction runs through black American life. As many of us still suffer from deprivations caused by historical racism, we also live in a society where racism is simply no longer a significant barrier to black advancement -- a society so sensitized that even the implication of racism, as in the Henry Louis Gates case, triggers a national discussion.



We blacks know oppression well, but today it is our inexperience with freedom that holds us back almost as relentlessly as oppression once did. Out of this inexperience, for example, we miss the fact that racial preferences and disparate impact can only help us -- even if they were effective -- with a problem we no longer have. The problem that black firefighters had in New Haven was not discrimination; it was the fact that not a single black did well enough on the exam to gain promotion.

Today's "black" problem is underdevelopment, not discrimination. Success in modernity will demand profound cultural changes -- changes in child-rearing, a restoration of marriage and family, a focus on academic rigor, a greater appreciation of entrepreneurialism and an embrace of individual development as the best road to group development.

Whites are embarrassed to speak forthrightly about black underdevelopment, and blacks are too proud to openly explore it for all to see. So, by unspoken agreement, we discuss black underdevelopment in a language of discrimination and injustice. We rejoin the exhausted affirmative action debate as if it really mattered, and we do not acknowledge that this underdevelopment is primarily a black responsibility. And yet it is -- as historically unfair as it may be, as much as it seems to blame the victim. In human affairs we are responsible not just for our "just" fate, but also for our existential fate.

But continuing black underdevelopment will flush both races out of their postures and make most discussions of race in America, outside a context of development, irrelevant."

More to come, but does this a-hole realize how many resources we pour into development? He is mischaracterizing me--I KNOW that underdevelopment is the primary obstacle confronting black Americans. That's, e.g., why I see Affirmative Action as an important part of the playing field leveling process.

so at this point, i can just say i really like the two following books.  they're both collections of essays by black and brown people, as diverse in profession as they are in opinion about black success and black advancement and barriers to black progress.  

the first book is called America Behind The Color Line, edited by Henry Louis Gates, Jr.  It has essays by him, Morgan Freeman, Russell Simmons, Alicia Keys, and black professors and black CEO's and others.  This book helps lay out the range of opinion on this stuff.    

The second book, which would take significant issue with black elite conservative thinkers like Steele, is called The Covenant With Black America.  It's edited by Tavis Smiley and has essays by cool civil rights lawyers like James Bell and doctors and others.  It's goal is to talk about what the black community needs and why, and what we can do about it.  It talks about health care, the criminal justice system, etc.  It is not "academic," but is rather a practical guide to what communities can do.  It's provocative, too, and rather enlightening with some statistics and some talk about problems.  Did you know, for example, that in 1954 there were 80,000 blacks incarcerated, and as of 2007 there are 910,000?   That's a 900% increase!  And the various miscarriages of justice just keep piling up.  It's frightening.  No barriers, Mr. Steele?  90% up to black people to "pick themselves up by their bootstraps," Mr. Steele? PROPOSAL

Roles: Lead, Moderator, Discussants.

1. Lead makes an argument, in a new thread. Premises and conclusion are numbered.

2. Discussion proceeds in response threads to the original thread. Results are recorded by the Moderator on the original thread.

3. Discussion proceeds serially as follows:

  a) form (deduction, induction, analogy, explanation, etc.)
  b) validity
  c) cogency/soundness

4. When discussion becomes heated, the Moderator may assign the floor to a Discussant as necessary (Lead and Moderator are also Discussants).

5. The Moderator determines when a phase of discussion has concluded (either through consensus, or vote as called by the Moderator, or "failure" as determined by the moderator), and records the result on the original thread (from #1).

I would propose that Rick and Christy be our first Lead and Moderator, respectively.

That looks slightly but significantly miscast, in that Steele seems to indeed be identifying impediments to black advancement. If we were to disagree with Steele we would have to posit a significant special *external* impediment to black advancement in this country (external, that is, to the black community itself).

Steele's argument seems to be: "Ok, affirmative action has done its job of jump-starting opportunity for blacks; now it's time for blacks to step up to the plate."

I think for Steele to be right, it is only required that the balance has shifted (between external and internal factors), not that external factors are entirely eradicated. (Though, as mentioned, shifted to what? 50/50? 10/90?)

So is he right? What specific external impediments still exist? Brainstorm:

- When a black kid is pulled over by cops, he is treated more harshly and with more suspicion.
- When a black guy ends up in front of a judge, he is treated more harshly.
- The grade schools that black children attend are worse than those that white children attend.

What else? And then, do these outweigh the internal factors such as Steele identifies?

Right, so the question, it seems, is, "Given sufficiently altered institutions, who then is responsible for addressing the underdevelopment remaining from past racism?" Steele's answer is, "the underdeveloped."

It defines, to an extent, the barriers that an individual encounters in their social maneuverability, etc., but it has only a *very* limited use in describing the objective reality of an Other.

So, it has great Subjective worth, but limited Objective worth.

These distinctions matter. You have to differentiate these purposes, these goals, these tools.
Or, to dichotomize wantonly, Prescriptive value=High, Descriptive value=Low.

One day Robin and I drove all around the inner-city  of Baltimore trying to decide whether to move there or Madison.

What we saw was very raw. I was expecting poverty and segregation, which of course we observed in spades, but what I wasn't expecting at all was what I perceived as (and can only begin to attempt to describe as) a bounteous surplus of an all pervading lawlessness, spread out thick across significant swathes of the city. It felt very much like Mad Max, sans Thunderdome, even down to a crazy guy we saw with long dreadlocks doing a wheely down the middle of a downtown street on a definitely non-street legal dirtbike. I may have fabricated the memory that he had a shotgun strapped across his shoulder, hanging down his back, but it could have been there, too. An hour later, we saw the same guy doing the same thing on the other side of the city. I don't know how it sounds, but for me that day it was surreal. I was struck by a profound sense of the otherness of that world. I don't even think The Wire does it justice--after having driven down those streets, I suspect David Simon of editing some of it out.

And it's not just one part of the city. Or even a few parts. Many, many parts are like that. Spread all across the city. Interspersed with affluent neighborhoods and industrial areas. The most bizarre city to which I've been.

All of which is to say that I would be very surprised indeed if Baltimore couldn't consistently outperform Milwaukee in its portrayal of the deplorable correlation of race and suffering in the United States of America.
A handsome girl, mind you.

i don't know much about this dude.  it seems he's had an experience growing up struggling ecomonically.  this is an experience that many people had, browned or beiged or yellowish.  the chinese built the railroads, the african americans worked the fields, the fins worked the fields, the italians laid the streets and gutters,  etc etc.  (forgive me, i don't know what the russians or the poles did, or many other groups' historical contributions.  i'd like to learn more about this.  i believe everyone, absolutely everyone, has made contributions).  anyway, my point is i think it's fair to associate himself with people who had these types of jobs.  

but there is a long tradition of smart and economically wise black persons.  the histories of spellman college and howard university just name a couple.  there are many others. (i'd also like to learn more about this).  so Barack Obama exists in that tradition, and that doesn't make him any less "black."    In other words, Obama's black in a different way than this guy's stereotype of "black."

Also, like me, I think this guy is euro-descended.  [new tab, google search.  ummmmm, yep], so he's considered and perceived as white.  thus, he has no idea what it means to be considered black or brown here, unless somebody tells him about it.  and i'm speculating:  i don't think he would've said "i'm blacker than barack obama" if he had any idea about it.  i'm guessing he doesn't.  Barack Obama has been successful.  Barack Obama has made a lot of good decisions in his life.  And Barack Obama has been in contexts where people have not been friendly to him.  I'd bet a hundred bucks he's been called a nigger before.  And I bet he's experienced different types of exclusion, sly remarks, and petty inconveniences in many different settings throughout his life, in virtue of the fact of his brownness, in virtue of the problem of whites (or others) feeling superior to him.  I bet if we asked him about it, he'd have 10 stories about it on the tip of his tongue.  That's why brown professors get arrested in their homes.  That's why, when we talk about racism with black persons, we TALK about racism - a given, something as familiar and common to their experience a U2 fan in Dublin.  We talk about the mechanics of it, how it works, and not whether it exists, or whether or not somebody's sources are reliable or credible, or who's doing what to "prove" the sincerity or salience of their perspectives about race matters.

This guy is only "black" in virtue of some similar experiences with economic struggle.  In that case, my italian grandmother, and my whole white extended family was "black."  My uncle laid railroad ties for 25 years.  So he's black, too.  And yellow.  But that's absurd, of course.  They're all white.  And Blago's white, too.  And that's a whole different world than Barack Obama's world.  (IMO)  :)

To adopt Whitacre's obsessive preoccupation with "abstraction," I would propose that persons made in the mold of Rush, Sean, & Glenn, and much/most of their audience, identify to a pathological degree with people who are just like themselves. They hate people who are different, even a little. This is why they tend not to be counterculture (very few Republican hippies), why they value socially conformative behaviors, and why they tend more often to be racist bigots than other types of people.

And, frankly, if you abstract that notion, who is more like you than you yourself are? Fundamentally, it becomes a question of self-importance, self-indulgence, and self-service.

You've heard all this before, of course, from the likes of Greenspan and his dreamgirl Ayn.

Which makes sense, because the last thing Ayn would want to do is spend even a moment in altruistic contemplation of horrors befalling some Haitian vermin. Everyone is responsible for their own self-interest, and if they're not up to the challenge of protecting themselves, then they, as Greenspan wrote in the NY Times, "...perish as they should."
i like those parallels, wayno.  i like them a lot.  i hadn't thought about it that way, to connect bigotry with self-indulgence.  interesting.

i'd also like to declare the "fuck you" to Pat Robertson.  his ideas are absurd on so many levels, it would take too long to list them.  i'd rather not.  suffice to say: the provincial belief index known as the Christian Right Ideological Sandstorm relaxes comfortable on the sofa with the far more popularized (and less malignant) White American Nationalism.  Nationalism is at least understandable - people are inclined to be proud of themselves and connected to their geographical locales.  From my point of view, their mistake is a sentimentalist nostalgia for "the old days" that never were the old days, when the "family" was "stronger" and/or more "moral," when life was so much "better."  They hunger for a reality that was always a fantasy.  It was a "reality" based on an index of partial truths buttressed by an imagined "community" that was never actually united in anything aside from a common interest for keeping the peace and living abundantly.  And that's something we all can connect with, I think.  From this perspective, people like Pat and Rush are just exaggerations of nationalism.  

I'd like to push against nationalism that sacrifices other awarenesses, other knowledges.  I'd like us to get toward uprooting the fantasies and examining the skeleton, and then being and behaving as though the skeleton matters, and then build from there.  I want equality at all costs, even at the cost of our parent's allegiances, even at the cost of our religions, even at the cost of our comforts and our agreements.  I wanna get beyond comfort, and then find comfort there - in the wild mixture of everything, in the thinking and the saying and the learning, in the anxiety of not knowing.

I went to the Ethnography Museum when I was in Geneva a couple years ago.  Nearly half the museum was dedicated to an anthropologist's studies of Haitian voodoo.  I learned a little about religious practices in Haiti.  There were tons of etched bamboo sticks with elaborate stories  and figures and animals on them.  There was a dark room full of fabric sculptures of people, made from fabric stuffed with something soft (horse hairs maybe, or stiff foams?).  They had small jagged mirrors for eyes, different colors of thread for the mouth and ears.   The bodies and hands were shaped correctly, creating a feeling that they were real people.  The room was dark with a tiny amount of light, and the people were situated on either side of the room.  You walk through the middle aisle and look at them.  It was really really cool.  I walked slowly through it, alone.  I felt shocked.  At certain points, I was fearful.  To this day, it was probably one of the trippiest and coolest experiences of my life.

thank you for this, Wayne.  i like this article a lot.  it reminds me a bit of a recent chapter of Ann Stoler's "Race and the Education of Desire" that I tackled this weekend, in which she launches critiques of European colonialist ideology.  Specifically, Stoler writes eloquently and artfully on Dutch and English colonial practices in India and Indonesia, tracing the relationship between the metropole and and the natives, and how they used racialized and class-divided taxonomies to establish and continually reinvent the meaning of who could be identified as truly Dutch and/or English.  With regard to Haiti, i imagine there are analogous dynamics and that "aid" has, as your article demonstrated, caused much more harm than good.  Those interested in the "locus of control" notion will find Stoler's work to be a resounding confirmation (and a useful series of additional information) to their perspectives on class and race power dynamics here in the US.

a) Yes, you did say "only in part," but I pressed the point because your contention really doesn't make the Family Feud top 5 of why people want to see it. 

#1, 2 and 3 would probably be David Wain, Michael Showalter and Joe Lo Truglio, the guys who wrote it, who also did The State, Stella, Wet Hot American Summer, The Ten (c.f. your boobs in the Bible observation) &others. While their humor is often crass or raunchy (or whatever deliberately quaint way you chose to put it), it's part of a veneer for metatextual humor and absurdity. One they have pulled back when necessary. I think of the Stella series of shorts, which had a lot of dildos, humping and sexually explicit references. When it got picked up as a TV series, that content was dropped -- as a complete gesture, though Comedy Central would certainly have been comfortable with its somewhat muted expression. As if to say they didn't need it.

But yes, it is kind of offensive, in the fashion of broad comedies. It was written in 1998 and is equivalent to a R-rated movie of then or now. But not extraordinarily offensive. I guess the poster (that I designed that to spec, and some venues have refused to display) is to blame. It has more nudity than ads for strip clubs, or than the show itself, which doesn't have any.

I guess what irks me here is that you are applying your critical apparatus to something you demonstrably know only a few inaccurate things about. Or maybe seizing on it for a metaphor that might not be appropriate. I saw that a lot with German critics, reviewing a movie that they are above (below? askance? does it matter? they're critics) seeing, and then making it about Bush.

b) I'm preoccupied with one: that the family, specifically the demographic roles of father, mother, son, daughter, kid, adolescent, grandparent, etc., is the final derivation of a culture that is gradually trivializing non-essential constructs, and is thus beseiged by agents of consumerist culture who will spend billions of dollars gesturing and adjusting it into the needs of production. That the definition, image, nuance and attendent anxieties of the family and its members will eventually be in their hands. (I think Adorno talks around this in Book 2 of Minima Moralia.)

On this score, the internet is like the pundits, artists, curiosities and slippery slopes we are preoccupied with: first herald, then symbol. Ultimately, and wholly, distraction.
